hotspots.hotspot:
Correct version:

During our last class, the professor handed out the entire semester's schedule.

Correct version:

Mr. Kirksten offered me a summer job as his assistant and I accepted it.

Correct version:

Our grandfather clock chimes every fifteen minutes all night long, and it drives me crazy.

Correct version:

Nora helped the little boy as he unsteadily crossed the floor.

scene.credits: (tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.

content.header: Can you complete these tired clichés?
content.correctText:
ANSWERS
1. Cool as a cucumber
2. Happy as a clam (or lark)
3. Calm, cool, and collected
4. White as a sheet (or ghost)

hotspots.hotspot:
Description

If your purpose is to describe something in your essay, your introduction might include vivid imagery with interesting details or ideas to engage the reader to the subject.

Define / Explain

If your essay’s purpose is to define or explain what a concept is, you might want to define key terms in your introduction.

Analyze

If you are going to analyze a topic in your essay, you may want to place the subject in context in the introduction. Recall that this means identifying the time and place, historically and geographically.

Cause and Effect

If your purpose is to write a cause and effect essay, you could begin the introduction with essential background information.

Argumentation

If you are going to take a position and write an argumentation or persuasive essay, your introduction might identify the controversial issue.

Narration

If you are writing a narration and telling a story, you may want to describe the location, characters, or initial problem in the introduction.

scene.credits: (tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (c)Photodisc Collection/Getty Images; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.
(tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (l)©John Lund/Drew Kelly/Blend Images LLC; (c)Andersen Ross/Blend Images LLC; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.

content.header: Your conversation with a reader of your conclusion:

hotspots.hotspot:
1

Reader: So What?

2

YOU: Let me show you how the points in the paper fit together.

3

Reader: Why should I care?

4

YOU: Because I’m giving you new meaning. I’m explaining how the sum of the paper is worth more than the parts.

5

Reader: Hmmm. This gives me something to think about concerning your topic.

6

YOU: Good. My job here is done!

scene.credits: (tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (c)A. Minde/PhotoAlto; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.

hotspots.hotspot:
1

Hungry lions padded silently into the sawdust-covered arena.

2

The biology teacher hastily scribbled his name on the course withdrawal slip.

3

A heavyset, perspiring man strained to lift the heavy wooden crate.

4

The happy yet weary tourists enjoyed a picnic lunch of sharp cheese, crusty bread, and spicy olives.

scene.credits: (tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.

content.text: Read the following passage carefully before you choose your answers. <font face='lc-Italic'>This passage is taken from a twentieth-century speech.</font> I have, myself, full confidence that if all do their duty, if nothing is neglected, and if the best arrangements are made, as they are being made, we shall prove ourselves once again able to defend our Island home, to ride out the storm of war, and to outlive the menace of tyranny, if necessary for years, if necessary alone. At any rate, that is what we are going to try to do. That is the resolve of His Majesty’s Government—every man of them. That is the will of Parliament and the nation. The British Empire and the French Republic, linked together in their cause and in their need, will defend to the death their native soil, aiding each other like good comrades to the utmost of their strength. Even though large tracts of Europe and many old and famous States have fallen or may fall into the grip of the Gestapo and all the odious apparatus of Nazi rule, we shall not flag or fail. We shall go on to the end, we shall fight in France, we shall fight on the seas and oceans, we shall fight with growing confidence and growing strength in the air, we shall defend our Island, whatever the cost may be, we shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills; we shall never surrender, and even if, which I do not for a moment believe, this Island or a large part of it were subjugated and starving, then our Empire beyond the seas, armed and guarded by the British Fleet, would carry on the struggle, until, in God’s good time, the New World, with all its power and might, steps forth to the rescue and the liberation of the old.

scene.credits: (tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.

multiple.question: What is the rhetorical effect of Churchill’s repetition of the phrase “we shall”?

answers.answer: An extended metaphor of the trials of the British people
An example of personification of Hope
A reiteration of the unification of the people of Britain in this struggle
An analogy between the people of Britain and their ancestors
A paradox between the struggle for freedom and the comfort of home

figure.text:
Sample Multiple-Choice Question
Read the following passage carefully before you choose your answers. This passage is taken from a twentieth-century speech. I have, myself, full confidence that if all do their duty, if nothing is neglected, and if the best arrangements are made, as they are being made, we shall prove ourselves once again able to defend our Island home, to ride out the storm of war, and to outlive the menace of tyranny, if necessary for years, if necessary alone. At any rate, that is what we are going to try to do. That is the resolve of His Majesty’s Government—every man of them. That is the will of Parliament and the nation. The British Empire and the French Republic, linked together in their cause and in their need, will defend to the death their native soil, aiding each other like good comrades to the utmost of their strength. Even though large tracts of Europe and many old and famous States have fallen or may fall into the grip of the Gestapo and all the odious apparatus of Nazi rule, we shall not flag or fail. We shall go on to the end, we shall fight in France, we shall fight on the seas and oceans, we shall fight with growing confidence and growing strength in the air, we shall defend our Island, whatever the cost may be, we shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills; we shall never surrender, and even if, which I do not for a moment believe, this Island or a large part of it were subjugated and starving, then our Empire beyond the seas, armed and guarded by the British Fleet, would carry on the struggle, until, in God’s good time, the New World, with all its power and might, steps forth to the rescue and the liberation of the old.

scene.credits: (tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.

multiple.question: The tone of the passage can best be described as which of these?

figure.text:
Sample Multiple-Choice Question
Read the following passage carefully before you choose your answers. This passage is taken from a twentieth-century speech. I have, myself, full confidence that if all do their duty, if nothing is neglected, and if the best arrangements are made, as they are being made, we shall prove ourselves once again able to defend our Island home, to ride out the storm of war, and to outlive the menace of tyranny, if necessary for years, if necessary alone. At any rate, that is what we are going to try to do. That is the resolve of His Majesty’s Government—every man of them. That is the will of Parliament and the nation. The British Empire and the French Republic, linked together in their cause and in their need, will defend to the death their native soil, aiding each other like good comrades to the utmost of their strength. Even though large tracts of Europe and many old and famous States have fallen or may fall into the grip of the Gestapo and all the odious apparatus of Nazi rule, we shall not flag or fail. We shall go on to the end, we shall fight in France, we shall fight on the seas and oceans, we shall fight with growing confidence and growing strength in the air, we shall defend our Island, whatever the cost may be, we shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills; we shall never surrender, and even if, which I do not for a moment believe, this Island or a large part of it were subjugated and starving, then our Empire beyond the seas, armed and guarded by the British Fleet, would carry on the struggle, until, in God’s good time, the New World, with all its power and might, steps forth to the rescue and the liberation of the old.

multiple.question: Words can carry a positive or negative tone.
Knowing your audience is not important when you begin an essay.
An introductory paragraph may change, depending on one’s purpose for writing.
On the AP Exam, you should not answer the questions you do not know.
You may receive college credit if you perform well on the AP Exam.

scene.credits: (tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.
